body_text.text: A SECOND RECORD OF TYPHLICHTHYS SUBTERRANEUS (PISCES: AMBLYOPSIDAE) FROM ARKANSAS.-The Southern Cavefish, Typhlichthys subterraneus Girard, is limited to underground waters and is rarely encountered. It has been reported from caves, springs, and wells in the limestone regions of northeastern Oklahoma, southern Missouri, central Kentucky, Alabama, and from a single location in southern Indiana. In Arkansas, a single specimen was collected in 1940 from a well in Randolph Co. (Woods and Inger, Amer. Midi. Nat., 58:232-256, 1957) . No additional specimens were reported by McDaniel and Gardner (Proc. Arkansas Acad. Sci., 31:68-71, 1977 ).

cite_spans.text: McDaniel and Gardner (Proc. Arkansas Acad. Sci., 31:68-71, 1977

body_text.text: On 3 Feb. 1979 , approximately 20 T. subterraneus were observed in Richardson's Cave in southeastern Fulton Co., Arkansas (T19N, R7W, Sec. 21) . A single specimen, Arkansas State Univ. Mus. Zool. (ASUMZ) 9064, was collected for identification purposes. This specimen is the first collected from Arkansas since 1940, and is only the second ever taken in the state (Woods and Inger, 1957) . The first specimen, Univ. Michigan Mus. Zool. (UMMZ) 133844, was, until recently, catalogued as Amblyopsis rosae (R. M. Bailey, pers. comm.), suggesting the difficulty with which the two genera are distinguished. The nature of the diagnostic characters precludes definite field identification of Typhlichthys, and recent "sight" records from northern Arkansas should be viewed with caution until the exact ranges of Amblyopsis and Typhlichthys are determined in this region. We have examined UMMZ 133844 and ASUMZ 9064 and note that both possess a typical single row of sensory papillae on each half of the caudal fin.

According to Barr and Kuehne (Annals de Speleologie, 26:1-97, 1971) , Poulson (Amer. Midi. Nat., 70:257-290, 1963) , and Poulson and White (Science, 165:971-981, 1969) , Typhlichthys occupies slow moving waters or non-flowing pools remote from cave entrances, where minimal food is available. Our observations are consistent with these reports. We encountered Typhlichthys approximately 70 m from the entrance of the cave, in a pool that varied from 0.8 to 2 m in depth, 1 to 2 m in width, and 2 to 2.6 m in length. The substrate was predominately clay, and a brief check failed to reveal a source of food (no macroinvertebrates were present).

ASUMZ has 9 dorsal fin rays, 7 anal fin rays, and is 32.2 mm in standard length; the other fish we observed were of a similar size. Detailed behavioral observation was not possible, as negative phototaxis was pronounced; immediately upon exposure to our light sources, the fish began to disappear beneath a wall at the deepest part of the pool. On a subsequent trip (10 Feb. 1979) , water in the cave had dropped below the level of the previous pool, revealing communication with a small underground stream. No evidence of the fish was found at this time.

The Southern Cavefish is considered rare and endangered in Arkansas (Buchanan, Arkansas Natural Area Plan, pp. 85-86, 1974) and it has been proposed that any cave harboring a population of Typhlichthys be acquired as a sanctuary. It is doubtful that such a practice would actually provide protection for this species. Due to the anastomotic groundwater pattern of northern Arkansas, a population of Typhlichthys likely inhabits a system of interlaced subterranean streams, making the sanctuary concept ineffective at best. It would appear that exploitation by collectors and general groundwater pollution represent the greatest threat to the continued survival of this species in Arkansas. Conservation efforts should address these problems in the future.

We are grateful to Dr. Reeve M. Bailey for the loan of the UMMZ specimen.-KEN N. PAIGE, C. RENN TUMLISON, and V. RICK MCDANIEL, Dept. of Biological Science, Arkansas State Univ., State University, AR 72467.

OKLAHOMA.-The coyote (Canis latrans) is one of the few North American carnivores that not only has withstood human encroachment, but has expanded its range. Its ability to adapt its diet probably has contributed significantly to this range expansion. Ellis and Schemnitz (Proc. Oklahoma Acad. Sci., 1957:180-185, 1957) and Ellis (Oklahoma State Univ. Publ., 56:1-31, 1959) reported foods eaten by coyotes in northwestern and north-central Oklahoma, respectively. These are the only studies reporting the diet of Oklahoma coyotes. The purpose of this study was to add information on the frequency and seasonality of foods in the coyote's diet in central Oklahoma.

A SECOND RECORD OF TYPHLICHTHYS SUBTERRANEUS (PISCES: AMBLYOPSIDAE) FROM ARKANSAS.-The Southern Cavefish, Typhlichthys subterraneus Girard, is limited to underground waters and is rarely encountered. It has been reported from caves, springs, and wells in the limestone regions of northeastern Oklahoma, southern Missouri, central Kentucky, Alabama, and from a single location in southern Indiana. In Arkansas, a single specimen was collected in 1940 from a well in Randolph Co. (Woods and Inger, Amer. Midi. Nat., 58:232-256, 1957) . No additional specimens were reported by McDaniel and Gardner (Proc. Arkansas Acad. Sci., 31:68-71, 1977 ).

body_text.text: On 3 Feb. 1979, approximately 20 T. subterraneus were observed in Richardson's Cave in southeastern Fulton Co., Arkansas (T19N, R7W, Sec. 21). A single specimen, Arkansas State Univ. Mus. Zool. (ASUMZ) 9064, was collected for identification purposes. This specimen is the first collected from Arkansas since 1940, and is only the second ever taken in the state (Woods and Inger, 1957) . The first specimen, Univ. Michigan Mus. Zool. (UMMZ) 133844, was, until recently, catalogued as Amblyopsis rosae (R. M. Bailey, pers. comm.), suggesting the difficulty with which the two genera are distinguished. The nature of the diagnostic characters precludes definite field identification of Typhlichthys, and recent "sight" records from northern Arkansas should be viewed with caution until the exact ranges of Amblyopsis and Typhlichthys are determined in this region. We have examined UMMZ 133844 and ASUMZ 9064 and note that both possess a typical single row of sensory papillae on each half of the caudal fin.

According to Barr and Kuehne (Annals de Speleologie, 26:1-97, 1971), Poulson (Amer. Midi. Nat., 70:257-290, 1963) , and Poulson and White (Science, 165:971-981, 1969) , Typhlichthys occupies slow moving waters or non-flowing pools remote from cave entrances, where minimal food is available. Our observations are consistent with these reports. We encountered Typhlichthys approximately 70 m from the entrance of the cave, in a pool that varied from 0.8 to 2 m in depth, 1 to 2 m in width, and 2 to 2.6 m in length. The substrate was predominately clay, and a brief check failed to reveal a source of food (no macroinvertebrates were present).

ASUMZ has 9 dorsal fin rays, 7 anal fin rays, and is 32.2 mm in standard length; the other fish we observed were of a similar size. Detailed behavioral observation was not possible, as negative phototaxis was pronounced; immediately upon exposure to our light sources, the fish began to disappear beneath a wall at the deepest part of the pool. On a subsequent trip (10 Feb. 1979), water in the cave had dropped below the level of the previous pool, revealing communication with a small underground stream. No evidence of the fish was found at this time.

The Southern Cavefish is considered rare and endangered in Arkansas (Buchanan, Arkansas Natural Area Plan, pp. [85] [86] 1974) and it has been proposed that any cave harboring a population of Typhlichthys be acquired as a sanctuary. It is doubtful that such a practice would actually provide protection for this species. Due to the anastomotic groundwater pattern of northern Arkansas, a population of Typhlichthys likely inhabits a system of interlaced subterranean streams, making the sanctuary concept ineffective at best. It would appear that exploitation by collectors and general groundwater pollution represent the greatest threat to the continued survival of this species in Arkansas. Conservation efforts should address these problems in the future.

We are grateful to Dr. Reeve M. Bailey for the loan of the UMMZ specimen.-KEN N. PAIGE, C. RENN TUMLISON, and V. RICK MCDANIEL, Dept. of Biological Science, Arkansas State Univ., State University, AR 72467.

OKLAHOMA.-The coyote (Canis latrans) is one of the few North American carnivores that not only has withstood human encroachment, but has expanded its range. Its ability to adapt its diet probably has contributed significantly to this range expansion.

Ellis and Schemnitz (Proc. Oklahoma Acad. Sci., 1957 :180-185, 1957 and Ellis (Oklahoma State Univ. Publ., 56:1-31, 1959) reported foods eaten by coyotes in northwestern and north-central Oklahoma, respectively. These are the only studies reporting the diet of Oklahoma coyotes. The purpose of this study was to add information on the frequency and seasonality of foods in the coyote's diet in central Oklahoma. THE SOUTHWESTERN NATURALIST 26(1):67-92 THE SOUTHWESTERN NATURALIST 26(1): 67-92 FEBRUARY 21, 1981 FEBRUARY 21, 1981 This content downloaded from 35.7.39.109 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 13:18:18 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms Insects were in 25% of the stomachs (Table 1) . Except for one adult fly, all insects were grasshoppers and beetles. Summer was the peak season for insect consumption, but several stomachs contained insects during the cooler months as well.

Cottontail rabbits were in 13.9% of the stomachs, and avian remains were found in eight of 136 stomachs (Table 1) . Sheep occurred once; this coyote was one of three from the only sheep ranch sampled. Watermelon also was found once. One farmer in our study area attributed considerable losses of watermelons to coyotes; our specimen was from his farm. The five stomachs with persimmons were collected from September to January. Our category of "other plant material" includes sticks, twigs, and larger pieces of woody plants. Nearly one-half (61 of 136) of the stomachs contained at least some woody materials. Since trapped coyotes tend to ingest almost anything within reach, the high frequency of woody material probably can be attributed to this behavior. Likewise, the 28.7% occurrence of coyote toes and/or hair, the 13.2% with trap canvas, and the 5.2% with sand and gravel probably can be explained on this basis.

"Unidentified seeds" represented at least four different species of plants. Five species of mammals also occurred at low frequencies ( Table 1 ). The nine-banded armadillo and muskrat were found once, the harvest mouse twice, and the eastern woodrat and pine vole were each found three times. These species occurred at lower densities in the study area than cotton rats, cottontails, and pocket gophers. Cattle (probably carrion) were the predominant source of food throughout the year for our sample of central Oklahoma coyotes. Grasses occurred at a high frequency in the stomachs we examined. We suggest that future studies list grasses as a food item and, if possible, direct some efforts to determining the significance of grasses in the coyote's diet.

We sincerely thank J. W. Crews of the U.S. Fish and Wildl. Serv. for providing the specimens. Rogers, Southwestern Nat., 9:205, 1964; Allen, Bats, Dover Publ., 1962) and by direct of raptors capturing bats (Looney, Bull. Oklahoma Ornith. Soc., 5:1-4, 1972; St 43:137-39, 1941; Twente, Wilson Bull., 66:135-36, 1954) .

The pursuit and capture techniques used by raptors preying on bats have been de Red-tailed Hawk, American Kestrel, Peregrine Falcon, and Barn Owl (Looney, 1972) the Bat Falcon (Amadon and Brown, Eagles, Hawks, and Falcons of the World, New York, 1969) and Mississippi Kite (Taylor, J. Mamm., 45:300-301, 1964) . The Owl eats bats (Taylor, 1964; Baker, Condor, 64:500-504, 1962) , but its methods of pu ture are unknown.

cite_spans.text: Kestrel, Peregrine Falcon, and Barn Owl (Looney, 1972)

body_text.text: On several occasions between 1976 and 1978, a pair of Great Horned Owls was observed exiting a roost just inside the entrance to the Vickery Cave system, a Mexican free-tailed bat (Tadarida brasiliensis) maternity cave in Major Co. near Woodward, Oklahoma. Owl pellets found inside the cave entrance contained skeletal remains of Tadarida. The owls, when flushed, always left the cave and perched several hundred yards south of the cave entrance in a juniper overlooking the ravine which the bats follow on their exit flight. On 15 Sep. 1979, the exit flight began at 1845 during twilight. One of the owls approached the swarm of bats from behind but on a parallel path. The owl glided into the center of the bat swarm, singled out a bat, reached out with its talons and captured it. For approximately another half hour no more attacks by the owls were noted. Looney (1972) observed a Barn Owl using tactics similar to the Great Horned Owl. It dropped from a cliff overlooking the entrance of a bat cave and flew parallel with and into the emerging bat column, singling out and catching bats from behind. The owl captured seven bats in 45 min.

The similar attack behavior by the Barn Owl and Great Horned Owl seems to be different from those of other raptors. By gliding parallel with and into the bat swarm, both species minimized Insects were in 25% of the stomachs (Table 1) . Except for one adult fly, all insects were grasshoppers and beetles. Summer was the peak season for insect consumption, but several stomachs contained insects during the cooler months as well.

Cottontail rabbits were in 13.9% of the stomachs, and avian remains were found in eight of 136 stomachs (Table 1) . Sheep occurred once; this coyote was one of three from the only sheep ranch sampled. Watermelon also was found once. One farmer in our study area attributed considerable losses of watermelons to coyotes; our specimen was from his farm. The five stomachs with persimmons were collected from September to January. Our category of "other plant material" includes sticks, twigs, and larger pieces of woody plants. Nearly one-half (61 of 136) of the stomachs contained at least some woody materials. Since trapped coyotes tend to ingest almost anything within reach, the high frequency of woody material probably can be attributed to this behavior. Likewise, the 28.7% occurrence of coyote toes and/or hair, the 13.2% with trap canvas, and the 5.2% with sand and gravel probably can be explained on this basis.

"Unidentified seeds" represented at least four different species of plants. Five species of mammals also occurred at low frequencies ( Table 1 ). The nine-banded armadillo and muskrat were found once, the harvest mouse twice, and the eastern woodrat and pine vole were each found three times. These species occurred at lower densities in the study area than cotton rats, cottontails, and pocket gophers. Cattle (probably carrion) were the predominant source of food throughout the year for our sample of central Oklahoma coyotes. Grasses occurred at a high frequency in the stomachs we examined. We suggest that future studies list grasses as a food item and, if possible, direct some efforts to determining the significance of grasses in the coyote's diet.

We sincerely thank J. W. Crews of the U.S. Fish and Wildl. Serv. for providing the specimens. (Constantine, Bull. Natl. Speleol. Soc., 10:100, 19 Rogers, Southwestern Nat., 9:205, 1964; Allen, Bats, Dover Publ., 1962) and by direct of raptors capturing bats (Looney, Bull. Oklahoma Ornith. Soc., 5:1-4, 1972; St 43:137-39, 1941; Twente, Wilson Bull., 66:135-36, 1954) .
